newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Carne, film legend whose star dimmed.
newsitem.headline: France's Carne, film legend whose star dimmed.

text.p: France's Marcel Carne, who died on Thursday aged 90, fathered a cinematic legend in the 1930s but his later films never recaptured the success of his golden years and his last project collapsed because of lack of funds.

Carne won widespread acclaim for classics "Les Enfants du Paradis" and "Hotel du Nord" in the 1930s and 1940s, and worked consistently for three decades after World War Two. But his post-war career was plagued by critical and commercial setbacks.

In 1992 the veteran director attempted to relaunch his film career after a 20-year break, at the age of 83. He based his planned "Mouche" on a short story by the 19th century French writer Guy de Maupassant set in 1875, the year impressionist painting burst on the art world.

But the film based on a boat trip by five young men and the young painter's model they had all fallen for was never made. Shortly after filming had started, funding problems forced a halt and the production company later went bankrupt.

Despite his age, Carne had proved his stamina at the 1992 Cannes film festival, partying until the early hours every night. "I still have energy and a certain freshness," the short, pudgy director said at the time.
Born in Paris in 1906, Carne was brought up largely by his grandmother and an aunt. His father, a carpenter, was often away and his mother had died when he was five years old.
After minimal schooling, his family urged him to become an apprentice in his father's trade but he preferred to start out in an insurance office.
Obsessed by the cinema early on, he took lessons in photography at the Paris arts and crafts school, which did not offer film-making courses.
His stint as editor of Film-Hebdo magazine ended abruptly when Carne resigned in protest at a disparaging remark made by the magazine's owner about Charles Chaplin.
On a visit to a studio, he was hired as an assistant by director Jacques Feyder, and then Rene Clair to make "Sous les Toits de Paris" in 1930.
Six years later he had his first opportunity to direct a full-length production, "Jenny", forging close ties with poet Jacques Prevert and composer Joseph Kosma.

"Quai des Brumes", starring Jean Gabin, was a critical and box-office success. "L'Hotel du Nord" (1938) is still regarded as a classic of French cinema, with one of the most memorable lines of dialogue -- Arletty's rasping, derisive pronunciation of the single word "atmosphere".

The wartime pro-Nazi Vichy regime bridled at Carne's unconcealed left-wing sympathies coupled with fatalism, and he turned away from portrayals of the contemporary scene to make two of his finest works.

"Les Visiteurs du Soir" (1942) drew viewers into a medieval drama world, and "Les Enfants du Paradis" (1943), with its prodigious cast including Arletty, Pierre Brasseur and Jean-Louis Barrault, evoked the sleazy street life of Paris in the mid-19th century.

But he was hit by the end of his partnership with scriptwriter and poet Jacques Prevert in 1947, and then by the arrival of the French "new wave" in the late 1950s which rejected his classical style of film-making.
Only "Therese Raquin" (1953), based on the novel by Zola, found favour with the public.

His last feature film was made in 1974, he shot a documentary about the Bible, worked on giant photo collages that he exhibited around the world and supervised the transformation of his own films into colour.
It was not old age that caused Carne, honoured when France celebrated the 100th anniversary of film in 1995, to stop. He never lost his energy or love of talking.
"The last couple of films I made were not a success. I didn't want to become academic and dry," he said.
With his ginger hair nearly all lost, his knees arthritic, he added: "I'm not a magician. I have to watch out. I can't expect to maintain the energy of a 20-year-old."
